A return path for the magnetic field is provided about a periphery of the adhesively-attached component via a peripheral pedestal

is a perspective view of a component removal tool removing an adhesively-attached component from a circuit board assembly. In , component removal tool  is in the process of removing adhesively-attached component  from circuit board assembly . Component removal tool  is configured to heat to adhesives that attach adhesively-attached component  from circuit board assembly , so as to reduce the adhesion of adhesively-attached component  to circuit board assembly . When such adhesives are heated, the adhesion of adhesively-attached component  to circuit board assembly  can be significant reduced so that removal of adhesively-attached component  from circuit board assembly  is possible. Various types of adhesives can be used to attach adhesively-attached component  to circuit board assembly . Various solders, metals, and other adhesives are commonly used to attach electronic components to such circuit board assemblies, such as circuit board assembly . Such various adhesives can be used for conductive connection between leads of adhesively-attached component  and conduction traces of circuit board assembly . Some adhesives can be used for physical attachment only of adhesively-attached component  and circuit board assembly .

Component removal tool  heats the adhesives used to attach adhesively-attached component  to circuit board assembly  either directly or indirectly using inductive heating techniques, as will be explained in more detail below. Component removal tool  includes coil driver , inductive coil , and complementary high-permeability members T and B. Complementary pair of high-permeability members T and B can be positioned on opposite sides of circuit board assembly  about adhesively-attached component . At least one of complementary pair the of high-permeability members T and B includes central pedestal T. In the depicted embodiment, top high-permeability member T includes central pedestal T. “Top” here refers to the one of complementary high-permeability members T and B that is situated on the same side of circuit board assembly  as the side that adhesively-attached component  is situated. The term “bottom” is used to refer to the other one of complementary high-permeability members T and B that is situated on the opposite side of circuit board assembly  as the side that adhesively-attached component  is situated. The terms “top” and “bottom” need not be indicative of a particular orientation of circuit board assembly . Instead, the terms “first” and “second” can be used to distinguish between complementary high-permeability members T and B.

A magnetic field can be induced in complementary high-permeability members T and B via inductive coil  circumscribing central pedestal T of the complementary pair of high-permeability members T and B. Coil driver  is configured to generate an AC current in inductive coil  circumscribing central pedestal T, thereby inducing the magnetic field therein. Because high-permeability members T and B are made of high-permeability materials, any magnetic fields induced therein are channeled via the high-permeability members so as to minimize losses to the magnetic field induced. The magnetic field takes the path of “least resistance,” which is a metaphor for the closed path of highest permeability. By directing the magnetic field, via complementary high-permeability members T and B, complementary high-permeability members T and B shield from magnetic field exposure circuitry outside an interior cavity defined by interior surfaces of high-permeability members T and B. Only the circuitry within such a cavity will be exposed to the magnetic field.

At least one of complementary pair the of high-permeability members T and B has a peripheral pedestal. In the depicted embodiment both top and bottom high-permeability members T and B have central pedestals—central pedestals T and B, respectively. Central pedestal T is configured to direct a magnetic field induced therein through the adhesively-attached component. Peripheral pedestals T and B are configured to provide a return path for the magnetic field about a periphery of the adhesively-attached component.

In operation, complementary high-permeability members T and B are positioned on opposite sides of the circuit board assembly about the adhesively-attached component . High-permeability members T and B are positioned in clam-shell fashion so as to substantially enclose adhesively-attached component  within the interior cavity defined by interior surfaces of high-permeability members T and B. A magnetic field is then induced within high-permeability members T and B via AC excitation of inductive coil  by coil driver . The magnetic field induced is directed through adhesively-attached component  so as to induce AC currents with any conductive material within or below adhesively-attached component , thereby heating such conductive materials. Any solders, leads, circuit board traces, etc., which are located in this region where the magnetic field is directed will then heat due to these induced AC currents. Such heating can either directly heat the adhesives (e.g., if solder adhesives are located in this region) or indirectly heat the adhesives (e.g., via thermal conduction from the heated conductive materials to the adhesives).

One the adhesives have been heated, adhesively-attached component  can be removed from circuit board assembly . Various methods of removing adhesively-attached component  from circuit board assembly  can be employed. For example, top high-permeability member T can be raised, and adhesively-attached component  can be manually removed using a tool, tweezers, etc. In some embodiments, top high-permeability member T can be equipped with a suction system to as to vacuum attach top high-permeability member T to a top surface of adhesively-attached component . Then, by raising top high-permeability member T, vacuum attached component  will be removed thereby.

is a side-elevation view of an embodiment of a component removal tool configured to inductively heat an adhesively-attached component. In , adhesively attached component , is shown attached to circuit board assembly  via solder balls . Top high-permeability member T includes central pedestal T and peripheral pedestal T. Bottom high-permeability member B includes peripheral pedestal B. Inductive coil  is wound about central pedestal T. Top high-permeability member T together with circuit board assembly  forms cavity , within which adhesively-attached component  is substantially enclosed or encapsulated. Bottom high-permeability member B is aligned with top high-permeability member T so as to facilitate maximize the permeability throughout a closed path about and through adhesively-attached component . Such maximization of the permeability throughout the closed circuit path facilitates high magnetic-field strength, thereby producing high indictive heating of conductive elements that intercept the closed path.

is a side-elevation view of the component removal tool depicted in  with the magnetic flux indicated therein. In , the system depicted in  is annotated with magnetic field lines . Magnetic field lines  traverse a close path about and through adhesively-attached component . Magnetic field lines  correspond to a magnetic field induced by an AC current in inductive windings . Such an AC current in inductive windings  will induce a current in central pedestal T about which inductive windings are wound. This magnetic field will be directed about inductive windings  in a manner that traverses a path of least magnetic reluctance. Magnetic reluctance is inversely related to magnetic permeability. Thus, the magnetic field lines  will be preferentially directed in a path within high-permeability members T and B, as shown in the figure. Thus, magnetic field lines  traverse a path: i) from central pedestal T up to lateral field region T of top high-permeability member T; ii) then laterally outward from central pedestal T within lateral field region T to peripheral pedestal T; iii) then downward through peripheral pedestal T through circuit board assembly  to peripheral pedestal B; iv) then from peripheral pedestal B to lateral field region B; v) then laterally inward from peripheral pedestal B to a central region of bottom high-permeability member B; vi) then upward through circuit board assembly , solder balls , and adhesively-attached component , and back to central pedestal T again. Because magnetic field lines traverse circuit board assembly , solder balls , and adhesively-attached component , conductive elements, such as solder balls  within such a magnetic field will be inductively heated.

Thus, these lateral field regions T and B provide connect any central pedestals T and B (if present) with any peripheral pedestals T and B (if present), respectively. Furthermore, any central pedestals T and B as well as any peripheral pedestals T and B extends from such lateral field regions T and B, respectively.

This path in which the magnetic field is direction includes an annular region of circuit board assembly  that circumscribes adhesively-attached component  and a central region of adhesively-attached component  and a corresponding adjacent region of circuit board assembly . This central region through which the magnetic field is directed is proximate and defined by central pedestal . Peripheral pedestal T is located between adhesively-attached component  and other devices affixed to the circuit board assembly adjacent to the adhesively-attached components, such as, for example additional component . Additional component  is shielded from exposure to the magnetic field by complementary high-permeability members T and B.

is a plan view of the  embodiment of a component removal tool configured to inductively heat an adhesively-attached component. In , top and bottom high-permeability members T and B are depicted in plan view so as to appreciate a lateral extent of an example embodiment. Top high-permeability member T includes central pedestal T, peripheral pedestal T, lateral field region T, and inductive windings . In the depicted embodiment, central pedestal T has a square configuration. In some embodiments, central pedestal can be circular, rectangular or any other geometry appropriate for the specific adhesively-attached component to be extracted. About central pedestal T are show inductive windings . In the depicted embodiment, peripheral pedestal T is an annular pedestal that circumscribes central pedestal T without interruption. In some embodiments, in which the specific circuit board assembly requires interruption (e.g., due to a component located within the peripheral pedestal region), peripheral pedestal T can have one or more interruptions in its otherwise annular geometry.

Bottom high-permeability member B includes peripheral pedestal B and lateral field region B only. In other embodiments, bottom high-permeability member B can have a central pedestal as well as other features. For example, bottom high-permeability member can include an inductive coil, such as inductive coil  either in addition to or instead of inductive coil  wound about central pedestal T of top high-permeability member T. In some embodiments, peripheral pedestals T and B are complementary such that, when aligned with one another, peripheral pedestals T and B are substantially coextensive in their lateral dimensions.

is a side-elevation view of an embodiment of a component removal tool that facilitates both inductive and convective heating. In , adhesively attached component , is shown attached to circuit board assembly  via solder balls . Top high-permeability member T differs from those shown in the embodiments depicted in . Top high-permeability member T is configured both to direct the magnetic field induced by inductive coil , and to facilitate circulation of heated air into and out of cavity . To facility the circulation of heated air, top high-permeability member T includes input apertures , and output apertures . Such apertures can be used to provide circulation of heated air within cavity , which can be produced by a forced air heating system. Input and second apertures are thus configured to provide a circulatory path for convective heating therethrough. For example, a force air heater can force air into input apertures  and then receive air exhausted from output apertures .

is a side-elevation view of an embodiment of a component removal tool that includes a part extractor using vacuum technology. In , adhesively attached component , is shown attached to circuit board assembly  via solder balls . Top high-permeability member T differs from those shown in the embodiments depicted in . Top high-permeability member T includes part suction port . Part suction port  is a central aperture from an outside surface of top high-permeability member T through central pedestal T. A vacuum system can be fluidly connected to part suction port  so as to provide a suction that can cause central pedestal T to engage adhesively-attached component . Then, when solder balls  have melted (e.g., during reflow of the solder balls), top high-permeability member T can be removed, thereby removing component , whose melted solder balls  no longer provide adhesive attachment between component  and circuit board assembly . Part suction port  can be located in various other configurations, such as, for example, adjacent to central pedestal T. In some embodiments, for example, an annular aperture can circumscribe central pedestal T so as to provide an annular suction seal with adhesively-attached component .

is a side-elevation view of an embodiment of a component removal tool having a peripheral flux-transmission member, such as peripheral pedestal T configured to align upon a periphery of a component. In , adhesively attached component , is shown attached to circuit board assembly  via solder balls . Both top and bottom high-permeability member T and B differ from those shown in the embodiments depicted in . Bottom high-permeability member B includes no central pedestal or peripheral pedestal. Such a bottom high-permeability member, as bottom high-permeability member B can be used for circuit board assemblies, such as circuit board assembly , which have a planar surface on the bottom side adjacent to bottom high-permeability member B. Top high-permeability member T also differs in that peripheral pedestals T are configured to direct the magnetic field induced within top high-permeability member T through an annular periphery of adhesively-attached component . Thus, instead of directing the magnetic field through only circuit board assembly  in an annular region circumscribing adhesively-attached component , in the depicted embodiment, the magnetic field is directed through both the adhesively-attached component  and circuit board assembly . Thus, the magnetic field directed through such an annular region of adhesively-attached component  can provide additional inductive heating of conductive elements located in such an annular region.

title: Production system and production system control method

invention-title.#text: Production system and production system control method

nplcit.othercit: International Search Report dated Nov. 14, 2017 in PCT/JP2017/028744 filed Aug. 8, 2017.

abstract: It is an object of the present invention to provide a production system and a control method for the production system that can suppress erroneous mounting when a tape feeder is shared and used even when latest tape feeder information is not shared among multiple production lines in a production system having multiple production lines. Information that matches the tape feeder database stored by the line management device is stored in the tape feeder. When the tape feeder is mounted on the mounting machine, the information stored in the tape feeder is read, and when it is determined that the information does not match the tape feeder database, mounting of the electronic component supplied from the tape feeder is stopped.
description: The present application relates to a production system and a control method of the production system.

Patent Literature 1 discloses a production system including a line management device for controlling a work machine and a centralized management apparatus connected to the line management device, and the production system causes the work machine to continue work when a network failure occurs between the centralized management apparatus and the line management device. More specifically, the line management device acquires multiple pieces of control data in advance from the centralized management apparatus, and when a network failure with the centralized management apparatus is detected, the work of the work machine is continued based on the multiple pieces of control data acquired by the line management device.

When the work machine is a mounting work machine for mounting an electronic component supplied from a tape feeder to a board, the multiple pieces of control data may include collation information for preventing erroneous mounting. The collation information includes, for example, information on the arrangement of tape feeders in the slots of the mounting work machine and information on the type of electronic components that can be used by the mounting work machine. Further, for the purpose of collating information, it is possible to have a configuration in which the line management device stores tape feeder information in which tape feeder IDs assigned to the tape feeders are linked with IDs of electronic components held by the tape feeders. In this configuration, the collating is done in the following manner. First, when a tape feeder is attached, the mounting work machine acquires the tape feeder ID assigned in advance to the tape feeder and transfers it to the line management device. Next, in the line management device, the tape feeder information is referred to and collated with the electronic component ID linked with the transferred tape feeder ID, and it is determined whether the tape feeder and the electronic component held by the tape feeder are usable. When it is determined that the tape feeder and the electronic component are usable, the mounting work machine performs the mounting work. The tape feeder information is updated, for example, when an electronic component is attached to an empty tape feeder, when an electronic component is spliced to a held electronic component, or the like.

Incidentally, a tape feeder may be moved and used among multiple production lines. For example, when a tape feeder used in a first production line is moved to a second production line and an electronic component is added in the second production line, the tape feeder information stored in the line management device of the second production line is updated. However, when a network failure occurs, the line management device of the first production line cannot update its stored tape feeder information in accordance with the update of the tape feeder information stored in the line management device of the second production line. For this reason, when the tape feeder is returned to the first production line again, collation of collation information is performed on old tape feeder information stored in the line management device of the first production line, which may cause erroneous mounting.

In consideration of the above-described problem, it is an object of the present application to provide a production system and a control method of the production system which can suppress erroneous mounting when a tape feeder is shared and used, in a production system having multiple production lines, even when the latest tape feeder information is not shared among the multiple production lines.

The present specification discloses a production system, comprising: multiple production lines, each production line having at least one electronic component mounting machine; a line management device provided in each of the multiple production lines; a tape feeder having a mounting section configured to be mounted with a component tape in which electronic components are accommodated in a carrier tape; and a communication device configured to acquire a tape feeder ID assigned to a tape feeder and a component ID assigned to a component tape when the component tape is mounted in a tape feeder whose mounting section is not mounted with a component tape, and transmit tape feeder information to the line management device of the production line in which mounting is to be performed and said tape feeder, the tape feeder information including acquired tape feeder IDs and component IDs which are linked with each other; wherein each of the line management device and the tape feeder stores the tape feeder information when the tape feeder information from the communication device is transmitted; and the electronic component mounting machine executes a reading process in which the tape feeder information is read from the tape feeder when the tape feeder is mounted; a receiving process in which the tape feeder information read in the reading process, and an inquiry as to whether said tape feeder information and the tape feeder information stored in the line management device match, are transmitted to the line management device of the production line in which the tape feeder is mounted, and the result of said inquiry is received; and a stopping process which stops a mounting of the electronic component supplied by said tape feeder when a non-matching result is received.

According to the present disclosure, even when the latest tape feeder information is not shared among multiple production lines in a production system having multiple production lines, it is possible to suppress erroneous mounting when tape feeders are shared and used.

Embodiments of the present disclosure will be described below with reference to the drawings.  shows a configuration of board mounting production system (hereinafter, referred to as a “production system”) , that is an embodiment of the production system of the present disclosure, in which electronic components are mounted on a board such as a printed circuit board (PCB). As shown in , production system  includes multiple production lines , , only two of which are shown in , centralized management apparatus , and central management terminal .

Production line  is constructed with screen printing machine , multiple electronic component mounting machines , inspection machine , reflow machine , and work table , and is managed by line management device . Similarly, production line  is constructed with screen printing machine , multiple mounting machines , inspection machine , reflow machine , and work table , and is managed by line management device . In the following description, production line  of production lines ,  will be mainly described. Since production line  has the same configuration as production line , description thereof is omitted as appropriate.

Screen printing machine , for example, moves a squeegee along a mask with a squeegee moving device and prints a cream-like solder on a board conveyed in production line  through through-holes in the mask. The multiple mounting machines  are for mounting electronic components on a board, for example. Each of the multiple mounting machines  shares work according to, for example, the type of electronic component and performs component mounting work on a board conveyed by production line . Inspection machine , for example, inspects the mounting state, such as the mounting position, electrical characteristics, and the like of an electronic component mounted on a board. By performing heat treatment on the board, and melting and solidifying cream-like solder printed by screen printing machine , reflow machine  electrically bonds the board and the electronic component. The number, type, order of arrangement, and the like of the devices (i.e., screen printing machine  and mounting machine ) included in production line  shown in  are examples and are not limited thereto.
Work table  is used for preparing tape feeder , which will be described later, and has a holding table (not shown) for holding tape feeder .

Line management device  is, for example, a server device for management developed by the manufacturer of the work machine, such as screen printing machine . The user can manage production line  constituted by screen printing machine  or the like by operating line management device . Line management device  manages various types of data used in production line  and various types of information to be transmitted to centralized management apparatus , the details of which will be described later. Line management device  is connected to wide area network WAN, to which centralized management apparatus  is connected, and local network LAN, to which screen printing machine  and the like are connected.

Line management device , screen printing machine , multiple mounting machines , inspection machine , and reflow machine  are connected to each other via local network LAN. Line management device , screen printing machine , and the like mutually transmit and receive data through local network LAN by communication conforming to a unique communication protocol defined by the manufacturer of, for example, mounting machine  and the like. The communication protocol unique to the manufacturer is, for example, a protocol capable of transmitting and receiving data using a TCP/IP protocol.

Centralized management apparatus  is, for example, a server that is installed in a data center of a manufacturing company that manufactures a mounting board with production system  and collectively manages data of production lines ,  in each manufacturing factory in remote locations. Centralized management apparatus  is connected to line management devices ,  of the respective factories via wide area network WAN. Centralized management apparatus  transmits and receives data to and from line management device  via an internet line by, for example, a secure communication protocol.

The network configuration shown in  is an example and can be changed as appropriate. For example, centralized management apparatus  and line management device  may be connected to each other via a local network. For example, centralized management apparatus  installed in a management building on the same site as line management device  installed in a manufacturing factory may be connected to each other via a local network.

Centralized management apparatus  stores, for example, production planning data, control data, material data, collation data, quality data, and the like. Production planning data includes, for example, a production start time, a scheduled finish time, control data to be used, and data in which production schedules of production lines ,  to be operated are defined. The control data is data used for controlling each work machine, such as screen printing machine , mounting machine , inspection machine , and reflow machine , for manufacturing the mounting board. For example, the control data of mounting machine  is information related to the mounting positions of electronic components on the board, the type of electronic component to be mounted, the position of the feeders to be supplied, and the like. The control data of mounting machine  is linked with material data relating to the board and the electronic component. The material data includes, for example, information on the board and electronic components used in production in each of production lines , . The collation data is data used by each work machine to perform work as set. The collation data includes, for example, information such as the component type that can be used in the mounting machine. The quality data is, for example, data indicating the relationship of serial numbers such as which electronic components are mounted on which board.

Central management terminal  is connected to wide area network WAN, and is installed, for example, at the head office of a manufacturing company that manufactures a mounting board with production system . A user at the head office, for example, operates central management terminal  to create control data and production planning data, and transmits the control data and production planning data to centralized management apparatus  via wide area network WAN. Centralized management apparatus  transmits the control data in which material data is linked with each of line management devices ,  of production lines , , respectively, for example, in accordance with production planning data. For example, every day, centralized management apparatus  transmits material data and control data required for one day of production in accordance with the start times of production lines , .

On the other hand, when line management devices ,  receive quality data from mounting machine  or the like, for example, at the time of manufacturing the mounting board, line management devices ,  transmit the quality data to centralized management apparatus  each time quality data is received. For example, a user at the head office can check the occurrence status of errors in production lines ,  by operating central management terminal  to check quality data stored in centralized management apparatus .

Next, mounting machine  will be described in detail with reference to . Mounting machine  includes system base  and two mounting machines . Two mounting machines  are installed adjacent to each other on system base . Mounting machine  includes frame section , conveyance device , mounting head moving device , supply device , and mounting head . Mounting machine  mounts the electronic component to the board conveyed by conveyance device . In the following description, the direction shown in  is used. The direction in which the board is conveyed by conveyance device  is the X-axis direction, and the horizontal direction orthogonal to the X-axis direction is the Y-axis direction. Operation device  is provided on the front of mounting machine . Operation device  has a display screen, operation switches, and the like. The user can check information such as the operational state of mounting machine  displayed on the display screen of operation device . In addition, the user can perform necessary operations and change settings on mounting machine  via the operation switches of operation device .

Conveyance device  includes two conveyor devices , . Conveyor devices ,  extend in the X-axis direction and convey boards in the X-axis direction. Moving device  moves mounting head  in the X-direction and the Y-direction. Mounting head  picks up and releases the electronic component and mounts the electronic component to the board.

Supply device  is a feeder-type supply device, and is disposed at the front end of frame section . Feeder  includes tape feeder holding stand  for holding multiple tape feeders . As will be described later, tape feeder  opens component tape  () wound around reel  () while pulling out component tape  (), and feeds and supplies electronic components downstream from tape feeder .

Next, the operations of mounting work in mounting machine  will be described. The board is conveyed to a predetermined position by conveyor devices , . On the other hand, mounting head  moved to supply device  by moving device  holds electronic components fed out by supply device . Next, mounting head  moved to the mounting position of the board by moving device  releases the electronic component at the mounting position of the board. The above operation is repeated to mount the electronic component on the board.

Next, supply device  and tape feeder  will be described in detail with reference to . Tape feeder holding stand  provided in supply device  has slide section , upright surface section , and the like. Slide section  has multiple slots  that mate with rails  disposed at the lower end of tape feeder . Connector connecting section  and fitting holes  are formed in upright surface section . Fitting holes ,  are formed in the up-down direction with connector connecting section  interposed therebetween.

In addition to the above-described configuration, tape feeder  held by tape feeder holding stand  includes reel mounting section , feeder housing , sprocket , feed device , connector , standing pins , and the like.

Reel  is mounted on reel mounting section . Component tape  in which electronic components are taped is wound around reel . More specifically, in component tape , the electronic component is accommodated in the accommodating recess section of a carrier tape having an accommodating recess section and a feed hole, and a top cover tape is adhered thereto. Sprocket , feed device , and a separation device (not shown) are accommodated in feeder housing . Sprocket  is mechanically connected to delivery device  which rotates sprocket . Sprocket  pulls component tape  out of reel  by the teeth of sprocket  rotating in engagement with the feed holes of component tape . The peeling device also peels the top cover tape from the carrier tape. In this manner, tape feeder  delivers electronic components downstream.

Connector  and standing pins ,  are provided on side wall surface  of feeder housing . Connector  is electrically connected to connector connecting section  of tape feeder holding stand . Standing pins ,  are formed vertically with connector  interposed therebetween, and are each fitted into fitting holes ,  of tape feeder holding stand . Tape feeder  is powered via connector . Tape feeder  transmits and receives signals via connector . In addition, supply device  is provided with a detector (not shown) for outputting a detected signal to CPU  (to be described later) in response to tape feeder  being mounted on tape feeder holding table . Bar codes ,  are affixed to tape feeder  and reel , respectively. The details of bar codes ,  will be described later.

The holding table (not shown) of work table  () includes a slot (not shown) that fits with rail  of tape feeder  and a connector connection section (not shown) that is electrically connected to connector  of tape feeder , similarly to tape feeder holding table .

Next, a control system of line management device , mounting machine , tape feeder , and work table  will be described with reference to . Since the multiple mounting machines  and tape feeders  provided in production line  have the same configuration, only one of each will be described.

Line management device  is a computer or the like and includes CPU , RAM , ROM , HDD (hard disk drive) , first interface , second interface , and the like, which are interconnected by buses (not shown). Firmware and the like are stored in ROM . RAM  is used as a main memory for CPU  to execute various processes. HDD  stores tape feeder database , various programs, various data, and the like. The various types of data are collation data, control data, and the like. First interface  is connected to local network LAN. Second interface  is connected to centralized management apparatus  via wide area network WAN.

Mounting machine  includes CPU , RAM , ROM , first interface , second interface , and the like, which are interconnected by buses (not shown). ROM  stores programs and the like for instructing the respective sections to operate. RAM  is used as a main memory for CPU  to execute various processes and stores control data and the like transmitted from line management device . CPU  controls various devices such as conveyance device  in accordance with control data or the like. First interface  is connected to local network LAN. Second interface  can communicate with communication interface  (described below) of tape feeder  via connector connection  () of supply device  and connector  () of tape feeder .

Tape feeder  includes control circuit , memory section , communication interface , and the like, which are electrically connected to each other. Control circuit  is, for example, a circuit board, and memory section  is, for example, nonvolatile memory such as flash memory. As will be described later, memory section  stores tape feeder information  and splicing information  in which component IDs  are linked with feeder IDs .

Work table  is provided with communication device  and bar code reader  which are connected to each other so as to be able to communicate with each other. Communication device  is connected to local network LAN, and transmits the information read by bar code reader  to line management device . Communication device  can communicate with communication interface  (described later) of tape feeder  via its own connector connection and connector  () of tape feeder .
Production line  is provided with a bar code reader (not shown) configured to communicate with mounting machine .

In production system , various data such as production planning data, control data, material data, collation data, and quality data for a predetermined period such as one day are transmitted from centralized management apparatus  to line management devices ,  in advance, and the various transmitted data are stored in line management devices , . Then, in a predetermined period, production lines ,  produce in accordance with various data stored in line management devices , . As a result, even when a communication failure occurs in wide area network WAN, production lines ,  can continue production. Line management device  updates tape feeder database  in response to the user mounting component tape  in tape feeder . As shown in , tape feeder database  is an information grouping of information in which feeder IDs uniquely assigned to each tape feeder  and a component ID uniquely assigned to the component tape held by tape feeder  are set for each tape feeder . It should be noted that even if the same manufacturer and the same component type are used, the same component ID is not assigned to the component tape , and a different component ID is assigned to each component tape . In tape feeder database , a number indicating a supply order to be supplied to mounting machine  by tape feeder  is linked with each component ID. Tape feeder database  is used for collation, for example, when tape feeder  is mounted in slot  of supply device , as will be described later. Tape feeder database  is used to create traceability information included in the quality data indicating which electronic components are mounted on which board.

In production system , tape feeder database  is created for each production line. On the other hand, tape feeder  is commonly used in multiple production lines. Therefore, a method of mounting electronic components in a mounting machine without erroneous mounting even when tape feeder  is moved and used among multiple production lines will be described next by taking mounting machine  as an example.

As described above, various data of a predetermined period are transmitted from centralized management apparatus  to each of line management devices , . Line management device  stores the transmitted various data in HDD . Similarly, line management device  stores the transmitted various data in its own HDD.

The user prepares reel , which goes to tape feeder , on work table , for example, in a preparation period before the start of manufacturing. The production planning data includes information on which electronic components are to be attached to which tape feeder . Therefore, the user performs the preparation work according to the production planning data. Here, it is assumed that tape feeder  and reel  are assigned a feeder ID and a component ID, respectively, in advance. In addition, it is assumed that bar code  () indicating the assigned feeder ID is affixed to tape feeder . Similarly, it is assumed that bar code  () indicating the assigned component ID is affixed to reel . The user causes bar code reader  to read bar codes ,  during the preparation operation. Bar code reader  transmits the feeder ID and the component ID, which constitute information of the read bar codes , , to communication device . Communication device  transmits tape feeder information , in which the component ID is linked to the feeder ID acquired by transmission from bar code reader , to line management device  and tape feeder .

In the present embodiment, since communication devices such as communication device  are provided for each production line, such as production line , the user performs preparation work on work table  provided in production line  to which tape feeder  is to be mounted. Therefore, line management device  to which communication device  is connected via local network LAN, and to which communication device  transmits tape feeder information , is production line  to which tape feeder  is to be mounted. Line management device  updates tape feeder database  based on the transmitted tape feeder information . More specifically, line management device  adds the transmitted tape feeder information  to tape feeder database  and updates tape feeder information  as information having a “supplying order” of “1”. When tape feeder information  is received, control circuit  of tape feeder  stores the received tape feeder information  in memory section  and sets splicing information  to an initial value of “0”. Here, splicing information  is information capable of specifying the number of component tapes  mounted on the same production line to which splicing information  belongs.

Further, when the user splices and adds component tape  to tape feeder , bar codes ,  are similarly read by bar code reader . Further, communication device  transmits to line management device  additional information in which the component ID is linked with the feeder ID acquired by being transmitted from bar code reader . Line management device  updates tape feeder database  based on the transmitted additional information. More specifically, line management device  adds the transmitted additional information to tape feeder database  and updates the value obtained by incrementing the value of the “supplying order” already stored for the corresponding feeder ID of tape feeder database . That is, the transmitted additional information is stored in tape feeder database  as information of “2” or later in the “supplying order”. Further, communication device  transmits the information of the added component ID to tape feeder . When tape feeder  receives the added component ID information, tape feeder  stores the transmitted component ID information in memory section  as splicing information . The details of splicing information  stored in memory section  of tape feeder  will be described with reference to .

For example, it is assumed that component tape  having the component ID of “Z1111” is mounted on tape feeder  having the feeder ID of “CCC” in which component tape  is not mounted on reel mounting section . In this instance, tape feeder information  in which feeder ID is “CCC” and component ID is “Z1111” is transmitted to tape feeder  in which feeder ID is “CCC”. Tape feeder  stores tape feeder information  in memory section . Further, as indicated by information  in , splicing information  is set to “0”. Next, it is assumed that component tape  having component ID “Z2222” is spliced and added to component tape  having component ID “Z1111”. In this instance, tape feeder  having feeder ID of “CCC” is transmitted with information indicating that component tape  having a component ID of “Z2222” has been added. When the information is transmitted, tape feeder  updates splicing information  to “Z2222” as shown in information  of . Next, it is assumed that component tape  having the component ID “Z2222” is spliced and added to component tape  having the component ID “Z3333”. In this instance, tape feeder  having the feeder ID of “CCC” is transmitted with information indicating that component tape  having the component ID of “Z3333” has been added. When the information is transmitted, tape feeder  updates splicing information  to “Z2222” “Z3333” as shown in information  of . Further, when component tape  is added, tape feeder  similarly adds and updates the component ID of the added component tape  to splicing information . As described above, splicing information  is information in which the component IDs are spliced, that is, information in which tape feeders  are arranged in the supplying order to mounting machine .

shows an example of tape feeder database  stored in line management device  in the case of the above-described example. The number of rows in which the value of the item “feeder ID” of tape feeder database  is “CCC” is 3, which is the same as the number of component tapes  mounted on tape feeder  having the feeder ID “CCC”. The value of the “component ID” in each of the three rows is “Z1111” “Z2222” “Z3333”, and the values of the items of the “supplying order” are “1”, “2”, and “3”, respectively. In this manner, for the same feeder ID, the component ID whose value of the “supplying order” of tape feeder database  is “1” matches the component ID of tape feeder information  stored in tape feeder . In addition, for the same feeder ID, the component ID whose value of the “supplying order” in tape feeder database  is “2” or later matches the component ID of splicing information  stored in tape feeder .

When component tape  of tape feeder  is depleted by the mounting work of mounting machine , control circuit  of tape feeder  transmits information indicating that component tape  has been depleted to mounting machine . When mounting machine  receives information indicating the depletion, mounting machine  transfers the information indicating the depletion to line management device . When line management device  receives information indicating the depletion, the row of feeder ID corresponding to the depleted feeder in tape feeder database , that is, the row in which the “supplying order” is “1”, is deleted, and the values of the “supplying order” of the row with the “supplying order” of “2” or later are decremented to update tape feeder database . When splicing information  is stored in memory section , control circuit  of tape feeder  updates tape feeder information  by using component ID stored as splicing information  as component ID  of tape feeder information , and deletes first component ID of splicing information . On the other hand, when splicing information  is not stored in memory section , control circuit  of tape feeder  deletes component ID  of tape feeder information .

In addition, even when component tape  is spliced and added by the user in a state where tape feeder  is mounted in slot  of mounting machine , tape feeder information  and splicing information  stored in memory section  are updated. Similar to the preparation work, when the user splices and adds component tape  to tape feeder , the user assigns a number to slot , which will be described later, and causes bar codes ,  to be read by a bar code reader (not shown). The bar code reader transmits the number of the specified slot  and the read feeder ID and component ID to mounting machine . When mounting machine  receives the number of the specified slot  and the read feeder ID and component ID, mounting machine  transmits the component ID to tape feeder  mounted in the number of the specified slot . Control circuit  of tape feeder  stores the transmitted information of the component ID in memory section  as splicing information . In addition, mounting machine  transmits to line management device  information in which the component ID is linked to the transmitted feeder ID. When line management device  receives the information in which the component ID is linked with the feeder ID, line management device  updates tape feeder database  in the same manner as in the case in which additional information is transmitted.

Next, the collation process executed by CPU  of mounting machine  will be described with reference to . The CPU included in mounting machine  also executes the collation process. The multiple slots  included in tape feeder holding stand  are assigned numbers in advance in order to enable identification of positions. The collation data includes information indicating in which slot , among the multiple slots , tape feeder  holding component tape  should be placed.

When CPU  determines that tape feeder  is mounted in slot  based on the detector output signals, the collation process is initiated. First, in step S, CPU  causes second interface  to read tape feeder information  and splicing information  stored in memory section  of tape feeder . When CPU  reads out tape feeder information  and splicing information  via second interface , CPU  transmits signals to line management device  requesting collation of tape feeder information  and splicing information  (S). When CPU  of line management device  receives the signal requesting collation, line management device  determines whether the received tape feeder information  and splicing information  match with stored tape feeder database .

More specifically, CPU  extracts a row that matches the values of the received feeder ID in tape feeder database . Next, CPU  determines whether the component ID of “1” in the “supply order” among extracted rows matches the component ID of the received tape feeder information . When CPU  determines that the component ID whose “supplying order” is “1” matches the component ID of the received tape feeder information , CPU  then determines whether each of the component IDs whose “supplying order” is “2” and later matches each of the component IDs of the received splicing information . If it is determined that each of the component IDs having a “supplying order” of “2” or later matches each of the component IDs of the received splicing information , CPU  determines that the received splicing information matches tape feeder database . On the other hand, in the case that CPU  determines that the component ID having the “supplying order” of “1” does not match the component ID of the received tape feeder information  and determines that the component ID having the “supplying order” of “2” or later does not match the component ID of the received splicing information , CPU  determines that the component ID does not match tape feeder database . When the feeder ID of the received tape feeder information  is not recorded in tape feeder database , CPU  determines that the ID does not match with tape feeder database .

Here, when it is determined that CPU  does not match, the following cases are assumed. One is a case where component tape  is mounted in empty tape feeder  on which component tape  is not mounted, for example, in production line , which is different from production line  in which the collation process is executed, and is a case in which tape feeder information  and splicing information  stored in memory section  are stored. Further, for example, tape feeder  used in production line  is moved to production line  by the user, and a new component tape  is spliced in production line . As described above, when an inconsistency is determined in step S, it is considered that component tape  actually mounted on tape feeder  does not match the information of tape feeder database  stored in line management device .

CPU  of line management device  transmits a signal indicating “match” when it is determined that mounting machine  which requested collation is consistent, and CPU  transmits a signal indicating “non-match” when it is determined that mounting machine  is inconsistent. After executing step S, CPU  determines whether tape feeder information  and splicing information  transmitted to line management device  match tape feeder database  stored in line management device  (S). When a signal indicating a consistency is transmitted from line management device , CPU  determines that a match occurs (S: YES), and when a signal indicating an inconsistency is transmitted from the line management device , CPU  determines that a match does not occur (S: NO).

If it is determined that the electronic components are matched (S: YES), CPU  determines that the mounting of electronic components supplied from mounted tape feeder  is to be performed (S) and ends the collation process. On the other hand, if it is determined that the electronic components are not matched (S: NO), CPU  determines that mounting of electronic components supplied from mounted tape feeder  is not to be performed and stops the mounting of supplied electronic components (S). Next, a message prompting collation, such as “Please re-register the tape feeder” is displayed on operation device  (S), for example, and the collation process is terminated. By displaying the resume-collation message, the user becomes aware that tape feeder database  stored in line management device  and component tape  actually mounted on tape feeder  are different from each other. Here, collation and registration constitute a series of operations in which tape feeder database  is updated by, for example, causing bar code reader  to read bar codes , , same as when preparation work is performed during the preparation period described above.

After performing S, CPU  transmits to line management device  signals requesting line management device  to collate the number of slot  and the feeder ID with the collation data. Line management device  extracts the value of the component ID that matches the feeder ID transmitted from tape feeder database , and determines whether the value of the extracted component ID and the number of slot  match with the collation data. As a result, it is determined whether component tape  of tape feeder  attached to mounting machine  of the transmitting source is mounted in slot  having the same number as the collation data, whether component tape  can be used in mounting machine , and the like. If it is determined that line management device  is consistent, line management device  sends a signal indicating usability to mounting machine . Upon receiving a signal indicating the availability from line management device , mounting machine  performs mounting work of an electronic component supplied from tape feeder . Line management device  transmits the value of the component ID extracted from tape feeder database  at the same time as transmitting the signal indicating availability. Mounting machine  stores the transmitted component ID values in RAM  in association with the corresponding feeder IDs.

In step S of the matching process, when component tape  mounted on tape feeder  matches with tape feeder database , matching with the matching data is performed. As described above, since component tape  actually mounted on tape feeder  is compared with the matching data, erroneous mounting, for example, which may occur when comparing with tape feeder database  without having the latest tape feeder information, is suppressed. As described above, tape feeder database  is information used for creating traceability information. By using tape feeder database  used for creating traceability information, it is possible to perform a matching process for determining whether tape feeder database  matches component tape  actually mounted on tape feeder .

Here, production system  is an example of a production system, the mounting machines ,  are examples of electronic component mounting machines, production lines ,  are examples of multiple production lines, line management devices ,  are examples of line management devices, component tape  is an example of a component tape, and tape feeder  is an example of a tape feeder. Reel mounting section  is an example of a mounting section, and communication device  is an example of a communication device. Step S is an example of a reading process, steps S, S are examples of a receiving process, and step S is an example of a stopping process. The feeder ID is an example of a tape feeder ID. The component ID in which the supplying order of tape feeder database  is 2 or later is an example of first additional information. The information of the added component ID transmitted from communication device  to communication interface  is an example of second additional information. Operation device  is an example of a notification section.

According to the embodiment described above, the following effects are obtained. When component tape  is mounted on tape feeder , to which component tape  is not yet mounted on reel mounting section  of tape feeder , communication device  acquires from bar code reader , the feeder ID, being provided to tape feeder , and the component ID, being provided to component tape , and transmits tape feeder information , in which the acquired component ID is linked to the acquired feeder ID, to line management device  of production line , to which the component tape is to be mounted, as well as to tape feeder . When tape feeder information  is transmitted from communication device , line management device  adds tape feeder information  to tape feeder database  and stores tape feeder information . When tape feeder information  is transmitted from communication device , tape feeder  stores tape feeder information  in memory section .

When tape feeder  is mounted, CPU  of mounting machine  reads out tape feeder data  from tape feeder  in step S. In step S, tape feeder information  read out in step S and an inquiry, as to whether tape feeder information  matches tape feeder database  stored in line management device , are transmitted to line management device  of its own production line , and the result of the inquiry is received. In step S, the result of mismatching is received, and when it is determined that mismatching has occurred, mounting work of electronic components supplied from tape feeder  is stopped in step S.

A case, in which tape feeder information  stored in tape feeder  and tape feeder database  do not match, may be a case where tape feeder , in which component tape  is mounted in another production line, is mounted on mounting machine . In such a case, since the collation with the collation data is likely to be performed in tape feeder database  without having the latest tape feeder information stored in line management device , erroneous mounting can be suppressed by stopping the mounting of the electronic component supplied from tape feeder .

When component tape  is added by splicing to tape feeder  to which component tape  has already been mounted on reel mounting section , communication device  acquires from bar code reader  the feeder ID of tape feeder  and the component ID of the added component tape , and transmits additional information, in which the acquired feeder ID is linked to the acquired component ID, to line management device  of production line  to which component tape  is to be mounted. In addition, information of the added component ID, which is information indicating that component tape  has been added, is transmitted to tape feeder . When the additional information is transmitted from communication device , line management device  adds and stores the additional information in tape feeder database . When the information of the added component ID is transmitted from communication device , tape feeder  updates splicing information  based on the information of the added component ID. Therefore, tape feeder database  stored in line management device  matches the information stored in memory section  of tape feeder  in which splicing information  has been updated by communication device  of the same production line. In other words, when tape feeder  whose splicing information  has been updated in another production line is mounted on mounting machine , tape feeder database  of line management device  of the mounted production line does not match splicing information  stored in the mounted tape feeder . Therefore, the case where component tapes  are not aligned is, for example, a case where tape feeder  to which component tapes  are added in another production line is mounted on mounting machine . In such a case, since the collation with the collation data is likely to be performed in tape feeder database  without having the latest tape feeder information stored in line management device , erroneous mounting can be suppressed by stopping the mounting of the electronic component supplied from tape feeder .

When the information of the added component ID is transmitted, tape feeder  stores the transmitted component ID as splicing information . The component ID of added component tape  can be used as splicing information.
In step S, CPU  displays a message on operation device  to prompt resuming of collation. Thus, the user can recognize that tape feeder database  needs to be updated.

Next, another example of splicing information  will be described with reference to . In the above description, the case where splicing information  is configured by the component ID has been described, but splicing information  may be configured by the number of times of splicing.

Specifically, for example, it is assumed that component tape  having the component ID of “Z1111” is mounted on tape feeder  having the feeder ID of “CCC” in which component tape  is not mounted on reel mounting section . In this case, similarly to the above, splicing information  is set to “0” as shown by information  in . Next, it is assumed that component tape  having component ID “Z2222” is spliced and added to component tape  having component ID “Z1111”. In this case, tape feeder  updates splicing information  to “1” as indicated by information  in . Next, it is assumed that component tape  having the component ID “Z2222” is spliced and added to component tape  having the component ID “Z3333”. In this case, tape feeder  updates splicing information  to “2” as indicated by information  in . As described above, since the value of splicing information  is incremented each time component tape  is added, splicing information  is a number indicating the number of times of splicing.

In this configuration, when the user splices and adds component tape  to tape feeder , communication device  transmits information to tape feeder  indicating that component tape  has been added (an example of second additional information) to communication interface . When tape feeder  receives the information indicating that component tape  has been added, tape feeder  increments the value of splicing information . When component tape  is spliced and added by the user while tape feeder  is mounted in slot  of mounting machine , the bar code reader transmits the number of the specified slot  and the read feeder ID and component ID to mounting machine  as in the above embodiment. When mounting machine  receives the number of the specified slot  and the read feeder ID and component ID, it transmits information indicating that component tape  has been added to tape feeder  mounted in the number of the specified slot . When control circuit  of tape feeder  receives information indicating that component tape  has been added, control circuit  increments the value of splicing information .

When component tape  of tape feeder  is depleted by the mounting work of mounting machine , control circuit  of tape feeder  transmits information indicating that component tape  has been depleted to mounting machine . When mounting machine  receives information indicating the depletion, if a component ID whose supply order is “2” is stored, mounting machine  transmits the stored component ID whose supply order is “2” to tape feeder . As described above, since mounting machine  stores the value of the component ID transmitted together with the signal indicating usability transmitted from line management device  at the time of matching with the matching data, mounting machine  transmits the component ID in which the stored supply order is “2”. When the component ID is transmitted from mounting machine , control circuit  of tape feeder  updates tape feeder information  by using the transmitted component ID as component ID  of tape feeder information . When the value of splicing information  is 1 or more, control circuit  of tape feeder  decrements the value of splicing information  and updates splicing information .

The component ID is information for specifying, for example, a manufacturer, a component type, and the like, and is composed of multiple numbers, letters, and the like, and therefore, the amount of information is more than “the number of times of splicing” which is a one-digit number. Therefore, with the configuration of another example of the splicing information described above, since the amount of information stored in memory section  is smaller than the component ID, the capacity of memory section  and the processing time for memory section  to store the information can be reduced.

It is needless to say that the present disclosure is not limited to the above-described embodiments, and various modifications and changes can be made within a scope not departing from the spirit of the present disclosure. For example, in the above description, it has been described that centralized management apparatus  transmits various data of a predetermined period to line management device . In addition, for example, when line management device  updates tape feeder database , production system  may transmit the update information to centralized management apparatus  each time, and centralized management apparatus  may transmit the update information to another line management device. Alternatively, for example, line management device  may periodically transmit the update information. In the case of such a configuration, for example, when a communication failure has not occurred in wide area network WAN, the latest tape feeder database shared by multiple line management devices is stored. For example, even in a state where a communication failure occurs in wide area network WAN and the line management device is not updated to the latest tape feeder database, erroneous mounting can be suppressed by executing the matching process. Alternatively, when it is determined in step S of the matching process that there is no match, the line management device may request centralized management apparatus  to transmit the update information. In this configuration, when the request for transmission of update information is received, centralized management apparatus  may transmit a signal instructing transmission of update information to multiple line management devices.

For example, in the above description, production system  has been described in which each of the production lines such as production line  includes a work table such as work table , but the present disclosure is not limited thereto. For example, one work table may be provided for multiple production lines. In this case, which of the multiple production lines tape feeder  will be mounted on, that is, which production line is scheduled to perform mounting, may be inputted by a user, for example.

Further, in the above description, tape feeder information  and splicing information  have been described separately in the case where component tape  is mounted on the empty tape feeder  to which component tape  is not mounted and in the case where component tape  is added to tape feeder  to which component tape  is already mounted. For example, when multiple component tapes  are mounted on tape feeder  at the same time, communication device  may acquire multiple component IDs from bar code reader  and transmit to line management device  a grouping of information in which the acquired feeder IDs are linked to acquired component IDs in the supplying order.

In the above description, operation device  is exemplified as the notification section, but the present disclosure is not limited thereto. For example, in the case where line management device  is configured to include a display, information for prompting matching may be displayed on the display of line management device .

In the above description, the matching with the matching data is performed after the execution of step S of the matching process, but the present disclosure is not limited thereto. For example, when line management device  determines that the received tape feeder information  and splicing information  match the stored tape feeder database  in step S of the matching process, line management device  may perform matching with the matching data based on tape feeder database .

In the above description, line management device  performs matching with the matching data, but the present disclosure is not limited to this, and mounting machine  may be configured to perform matching with the matching data. More specifically, mounting machine  may be configured to store collation data, transmit the component IDs based on tape feeder database  from line management device , and perform the collation between the transmitted component IDs and the collation data.

Although tape feeder  has been described as storing tape feeder information  in which component ID  is linked with feeder ID , tape feeder  may be configured to store each of the feeder ID and the component ID.

The configuration of tape feeder database  is not limited to the above. For example, instead of the supplying order, the arrangement of component IDs may be identified by, for example, the date and time when information, such as the tape feeder information, is transmitted from mounting machine . In addition, line management device  has been described as deleting the row whose “supplying order” for the corresponding feeder ID of tape feeder database  is “1” when it receives information indicating depletion, but alternatively depletion may be determined without deletion, for example, by relying on the date and time when information indicating depletion was received.
